body_content.explanation: If something that is wrapped tightly around itself unspools, or someone unspools it, it becomes or is made straight:
examples: The fishing line got caught on my glove as it was unspooling.
The records were destroyed when staff tried to unspool the rolls of film.

body_content.explanation: When a film unspools, or someone unspools it, it is shown on a screen:
examples: This autumn, film adaptations of the two novels will unspool in cinemas.
An open-air screen on the public beach unspools old Hollywood classics each evening.

body_content.explanation: When a story or an event unspools, or someone unspools it, it develops or becomes known to people:
examples: Her new novel unspools deep in the English Lake District.
The plot unspools slowly, over several different timelines.
I think I have unspooled my rambling thoughts enough for one day.
They will wait to see how the legal battle unspools before taking a decision.

body_content.explanation: to become, or to make something become, less strong or less under control:
examples: Our carefully laid plans to get fit are starting to unspool in the face of chocolate cake and back-to-work stress.
As his biography shows, alcohol did unspool his mind a bit at the end.
